context.setting: Three-way video call between family members planning a wedding
context.background: Sister's wedding is 8 weeks away, vendor issues and family disagreements causing stress
context.tension_point: Budget overruns and family members have different visions for the celebration
context.expected_outcome: Resolve vendor crisis and align family on realistic expectations

participants.name: Sarah Thompson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Excited but overwhelmed, rapid topic switching
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more emotional and scattered
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I just want everything perfect' when stressed
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice pitch rises when anxiety peaks

sample_dialogue: I just want everything perfect, but the florist just canceled and we're already $3,000 over budget!
Mom keeps suggesting these vintage ideas that don't match my vision at all...
Marcus, you understand timing and coordination - tell me this can still work!

participants.name: Patricia Thompson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Practical advice, references her own wedding experience
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more controlling and detailed
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'When I got married' frequently
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets firmer when giving unsolicited advice

sample_dialogue: When I got married, we kept things simple and focused on what mattered - the marriage, not the party.
Sarah, you're making this too complicated - people remember good food and good company, not fancy centerpieces.
We need to get realistic about the budget before this gets completely out of hand.

participants.name: Marcus Thompson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Solution-focused, uses coordination and event planning metaphors
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Gets more energetic about finding creative solutions
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'We can make this work' when problem-solving
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets warmer when mediating between family members

sample_dialogue: We can make this work! This is like service at a packed restaurant - it looks chaotic but there's always a solution.
Sarah, let's break this down course by course - what are the absolute must-haves versus nice-to-haves?
Mom, your vintage ideas are beautiful - what if we blend them with Sarah's vision? Best of both worlds!

participants.name: David Thompson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Calm mediator, focuses on practical solutions
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more diplomatic and soothing
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Let's take a step back' when tensions rise
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets softer when trying to calm others

sample_dialogue: Let's take a step back - we all want Sarah to have a beautiful wedding, we just have different ideas about how.
Maybe we should focus on solving the florist crisis first, then deal with the other decisions?
I know a guy who does event coordination - want me to reach out and see if he has emergency vendor contacts?

conversation_flow.description: Sarah panics about florist cancellation and budget overruns, Mom offers unwanted advice, tensions rise
Marcus facilitates problem-solving, David suggests practical solutions, family finds common ground on priorities
Family agrees on budget limits, emergency plan for vendors, and compromise vision combining everyone's input

specific_assignments.task: Research emergency florists and get quotes by Tuesday
specific_assignments.context: Wedding is 8 weeks away, need vendor secured immediately

specific_assignments.task: Contact event coordinator friend for emergency vendor network
specific_assignments.context: Professional connections might have last-minute availability

specific_assignments.task: Create detailed budget breakdown with Sarah to identify cuts
specific_assignments.context: Need to get spending under control before more vendors

scheduled_items.purpose: Review vendor options and make final decisions on remaining planning
Lock in final budget and spending priorities

context.setting: Video call with extended family discussing nephew's college choices
context.background: High school senior accepted to multiple colleges with very different costs and career paths
context.tension_point: Family split between practical state school vs. prestigious expensive private college
context.expected_outcome: Help nephew make informed decision with family support

participants.name: Tyler Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Thoughtful but uncertain, weighs pros and cons carefully
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more confused and seeks validation
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I keep going back and forth' when uncertain
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Long pauses when considering life-changing decisions

sample_dialogue: I keep going back and forth - State has a great engineering program and I'd graduate debt-free...
But MIT has always been my dream, and the connections and opportunities there are incredible.
Everyone keeps giving me different advice and I'm getting more confused, not less.

participants.name: Linda Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Practical concerns, focused on financial realities
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more insistent about practical choices
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'We need to be realistic' about costs
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets tighter when discussing debt and finances

sample_dialogue: We need to be realistic about $200,000 in student loans - that's a mortgage payment for 20 years!
State University has an excellent engineering program and companies recruit there heavily.
I don't want Tyler starting his career with crushing debt when there's a perfectly good alternative.

participants.name: Marcus Thompson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Encouraging, focuses on opportunities and potential
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Gets more passionate about following dreams
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'This is your moment' when encouraging big decisions
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets more energetic when talking about pursuing passion

sample_dialogue: This is your moment, Tyler - how often do you get into MIT? Some opportunities don't come twice!
Think of it like choosing between a solid local restaurant and culinary school in Paris - totally different paths!
The debt is scary, but the network and opportunities at MIT could change your entire trajectory!

participants.name: Dr. Robert Chen

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Academic perspective, data-driven analysis
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more professorial and detailed
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'From an academic standpoint' when giving advice
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Pauses to consider long-term implications

sample_dialogue: From an academic standpoint, both programs will prepare you well - the question is about fit and goals.
The research opportunities at MIT are extraordinary, but State has excellent industry partnerships.
You need to think about what kind of engineer you want to be - researcher or practitioner?

participants.name: Aunt Susan

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Supportive, shares personal experience
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Focuses on emotional support and confidence
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Whatever you choose' when being supportive
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets warmer when offering unconditional support

sample_dialogue: Whatever you choose, we'll support you - but you have to live with this decision, not us.
I went to a state school and had an amazing career - it's really about what you make of the opportunity.
Trust your gut, Tyler - you're mature enough to make this choice with all the information we're giving you.

conversation_flow.description: Tyler explains his dilemma, family members immediately offer conflicting advice based on their values
key_points: MIT acceptance vs State University full scholarship

conversation_flow.description: Detailed discussion of career implications, Marcus advocates for dreams, Linda emphasizes practicality, Dr. Chen provides academic perspective
Family agrees Tyler should visit both campuses and make final decision based on fit rather than others' opinions
key_points: Family support confirmed regardless of choice
Focus on personal fit over external pressure

specific_assignments.task: Schedule campus visits and talk to current students at both schools
specific_assignments.context: Decision deadline is May 1st, need firsthand experience

specific_assignments.task: Connect Tyler with professors in his field at both universities
Research scholarship and financial aid options for MIT
specific_assignments.context: Explore ways to reduce financial burden if he chooses MIT

scheduled_items.purpose: Experience campus culture and meet with engineering faculty
Support Tyler in final decision before May 1st deadline

context.setting: Emergency family conference call after Dad's fall
context.background: 80-year-old father fell at home, can no longer live independently, siblings disagree on care options
context.tension_point: In-home care vs assisted living vs moving in with family, emotions and logistics clash
context.expected_outcome: Develop immediate safety plan and long-term care strategy

participants.name: Margaret Wilson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Crisis management mode, practical and urgent
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more controlling and decisive
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'We can't wait' when discussing urgent needs
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets higher when worried about safety

sample_dialogue: We can't wait for another fall - Dad was on the floor for three hours before the neighbor found him!
He's being stubborn about admitting he needs help, but this is about safety now, not independence.
I live closest and I'm seeing the daily reality - he's not eating properly and forgetting medications.

participants.name: Frank Wilson Sr.

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Defensive about independence, frustrated with children's concern
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more stubborn and resistant
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I'm fine' when rejecting help
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets gruffer when feeling controlled

sample_dialogue: I'm fine in my own house - one little fall doesn't mean I need to be put away somewhere!
I've been taking care of myself for 80 years, I don't need you kids hovering over me.
Those assisted living places are just waiting rooms for death - I'm not ready for that.

participants.name: Marcus Thompson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Mediating between perspectives, solution-focused
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Gets more energetic about finding compromise solutions
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'What if we tried...' when proposing alternatives
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets warmer when building bridges between family members

sample_dialogue: What if we tried a hybrid approach - keep Dad at home but with professional support during the day?
This is like designing a menu that works for everyone - we need options that honor Dad's independence AND keep him safe.
Dad, we're not trying to control you - we're trying to set up systems so you can stay independent longer!

participants.name: Thomas Wilson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Financial focus, research-driven approach
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more detailed about costs and logistics
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'We need to consider the costs' frequently
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Pauses longer when calculating financial implications

sample_dialogue: We need to consider the costs - in-home care is $4,000 a month, assisted living is $6,000, and that's just the beginning.
I've researched Medicare coverage and there are specific requirements for different types of care.
Dad's house needs major modifications for safety - grab bars, ramps, maybe a stair lift - that's another $15,000.

participants.name: Carol Wilson-Martinez

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Emotional support focus, worried about family dynamics
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more concerned about everyone's wellbeing
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'How is everyone holding up?' when checking on family
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice wavers when discussing emotional impact

sample_dialogue: How is everyone holding up? This is stressful for all of us, including Dad.
Margaret, you're carrying so much of this burden - we need to support you too.
Maybe we should look at assisted living places together as a family, so Dad can see they're not all depressing.

conversation_flow.description: Margaret describes crisis, Dad resists change, immediate safety concerns vs independence desires clash
key_points: Dad fell and was alone for hours

conversation_flow.description: Discussion of care options, costs, and logistics, Marcus proposes compromise solutions, family explores alternatives
key_points: In-home care vs assisted living costs

conversation_flow.description: Agreement on immediate safety measures and gradual transition plan that honors Dad's preferences while ensuring safety

specific_assignments.task: Arrange immediate in-home aide for daily check-ins and meal prep
specific_assignments.context: Safety concern requires immediate professional support

specific_assignments.task: Research Medicare coverage and get quotes for house modifications
specific_assignments.context: Need financial planning for long-term care options

specific_assignments.task: Research assisted living facilities and schedule tours
specific_assignments.context: Backup plan if in-home care doesn't work

specific_assignments.task: Coordinate family rotation schedule for weekend visits and support
specific_assignments.context: Ensure Dad has regular family contact and Margaret gets support

scheduled_items.purpose: Monitor Dad's condition and coordinate ongoing care
Assess effectiveness of current plan and make adjustments

context.setting: Video call between longtime friends after awkward money situation
context.background: Best friend borrowed $2,000 six months ago, hasn't repaid or discussed it, friendship getting tense
context.tension_point: Money vs friendship, awkwardness around expectations and communication
context.expected_outcome: Address financial issue while preserving friendship

participants.name: Jake Morrison

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Uncomfortable discussing money, defensive about financial struggles
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more withdrawn and explanatory
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Things have been tough' when explaining delays
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets quieter when discussing money problems

sample_dialogue: Things have been tough with the job market - I know I said three months but everything's taken longer...
I didn't want to keep bothering you about it when I didn't have good news to share.
You know I'm good for it, right? This isn't like me to just ignore a debt to a friend.

participants.name: Marcus Thompson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Trying to balance friendship with practical concerns
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Gets more direct about needing resolution
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I get it, but...' when addressing difficult topics
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets more serious when discussing relationship boundaries

sample_dialogue: I get it, but the silence has been harder than the money issue - I didn't know if something was wrong between us.
Look, we've been friends for 15 years - money shouldn't be able to break that up!
I need to know where we stand - both with the money and with our friendship.

participants.name: Amy Rodriguez

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Mediating perspective, relationship-focused
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Focuses on maintaining group harmony
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'You guys are both...' when mediating
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets more concerned when friends are in conflict

sample_dialogue: You guys are both handling this weird - Jake, you disappeared, and Marcus, you've been passive-aggressive about it.
This is exactly how friendships get ruined over money - by not talking about it directly.
Can we figure out a plan that works for everyone so we can get back to normal?

conversation_flow.description: Marcus addresses the elephant in the room, Jake explains difficulties, awkwardness is apparent
Amy mediates discussion about communication breakdown, friends explore feelings and practical solutions
Agreement on repayment plan and communication protocol, friendship boundaries clarified

specific_assignments.task: Set up automatic monthly payment plan for agreed amount
specific_assignments.context: Remove awkwardness by making payments automatic

specific_assignments.task: Stop being passive-aggressive and communicate directly about concerns
specific_assignments.context: Maintain friendship by addressing issues directly

scheduled_items.purpose: Get back to normal friendship activities without money stress

context.setting: Pre-holiday family planning call to avoid repeat of last year's disasters
context.background: Last year's family gathering was a disaster with political arguments and hurt feelings
context.tension_point: Family wants to gather but worried about repeating conflicts, need ground rules
context.expected_outcome: Establish guidelines and roles to ensure peaceful holiday gathering

participants.name: Helen Martinez

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: No-nonsense, focused on preventing problems
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more controlling about boundaries
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'I won't have a repeat of last year' when setting limits
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets firmer when establishing non-negotiables

sample_dialogue: I won't have a repeat of last year - Uncle Bill made everyone miserable with his political rants.
We're setting ground rules this time: no politics, no personal attacks, no alcohol before 4 PM.
Anyone who can't follow basic civility rules can celebrate elsewhere this year.

participants.name: Marcus Thompson

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Optimistic about family harmony, solution-focused
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Gets more energetic about planning positive alternatives
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'We can create something beautiful' when envisioning success
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice rises with excitement when planning positive activities

sample_dialogue: We can create something beautiful here - think of it like planning a perfect dinner party for people you love!
What if we plan activities that bring out everyone's best? Games, cooking together, sharing good memories?
I'm excited about this - we have the power to make holidays something everyone actually enjoys!

participants.name: Roberto Martinez

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Cautious, references specific past incidents
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Becomes more detailed about potential problems
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'Remember when...' before describing past conflicts
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Long pauses when considering family dynamics

sample_dialogue: Remember when Uncle Bill and Cousin Sarah got into that screaming match about immigration?
The kids were crying and Grandma left early - we can't put the children through that again.
Maybe we need designated peacekeepers who can redirect conversations when they get heated?

participants.name: Lisa Chen-Martinez

behavioral_traits.speech_patterns: Focuses on inclusion while maintaining peace
behavioral_traits.under_pressure: Worries about excluding family members
behavioral_traits.verbal_tics: Says 'But they're still family' when discussing difficult relatives
behavioral_traits.emotional_tells: Voice gets softer when worried about hurting feelings

sample_dialogue: But they're still family - how do we set boundaries without making people feel unwelcome?
Maybe we can assign conversation topics? Like everyone shares a good memory or something they're grateful for?
I want the kids to have good memories of family gatherings, not trauma from adult arguments.

conversation_flow.description: Helen establishes need for ground rules, family recalls last year's disasters, concerns about repeating problems
key_points: Last year's political arguments and hurt feelings

conversation_flow.description: Family discusses specific ground rules, Marcus proposes positive activities, Roberto suggests practical safeguards
Agreement on comprehensive holiday plan with rules, activities, and accountability measures

specific_assignments.task: Send ground rules email to all family members before gathering
specific_assignments.context: Everyone needs clear expectations in advance

specific_assignments.task: Plan structured activities and conversation starters for gathering
Coordinate with designated peacekeepers on intervention strategies
specific_assignments.context: Plan for redirecting conversations that get heated

specific_assignments.task: Prepare kid-friendly activities and safe spaces for children

scheduled_items.purpose: Final check on plans and assignments
Assess what worked and plan improvements for next gathering
